item.title: Drug woes won’t be tamed by US price regulations
item.description:
Nature, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03999-1

Drug woes won’t be tamed by US price regulations

item.title: Don’t overlook the value of co-supervision in PhD training
item.description:
Nature, Published online: 09 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03998-2

Don’t overlook the value of co-supervision in PhD training

item.title: China is leading the world on AI governance: other countries must engage
item.description:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03972-y

The nation’s regulators are attempting to match the rapid pace at which AI is evolving. That needs to become a global initiative.

item.title: Is your brain tired? Researchers are discovering the roots of mental fatigue
item.description:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03974-w

Better ways to measure cognitive exhaustion could point to treatments for long COVID and other debilitating disorders.

item.title: A breathalyser-style test for detecting pancreatic cancer
item.description:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03946-0

Surgeon George Hanna is developing a non-invasive test to catch one of the deadliest cancers before it’s too late.

item.title: What would an AI university look like and how might it change education?
item.description:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03950-4

From lectures by avatars to entire qualifications, higher education centred around AI is just around the corner.

item.title: Protected area management has significant spillover effects on vegetation
item.description:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09837-8

Analysis of effect sizes of vegetation spillovers from protected areas in Australia shows that 71% of over 3,063 analysed protected areas had a positive spillover effect, and that these effects covary with protected area management type.

item.title: Quantum computing ‘KPIs’ could distinguish true breakthroughs from spurious claims
item.description:
Nature, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04063-8

Researchers are devising ways to make new machines face off, without the hype.

item.title: This AI model ‘studied’ physics — and learnt to forecast extreme weather
item.description:
Nature, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04055-8

Combining artificial intelligence with a conventional climate model can predict heatwaves faster than the standard model alone.

item.title: AI tools aim to speed up outbreak modeling
